overview.short: Peptostreptococcus species are Gram-positive, obligately anaerobic cocci associated with human mucosal flora and polymicrobial anaerobic infections.
overview.clinical_context: Commonly isolated from abscesses and deep-seated infections (oral, head/neck, intra-abdominal, pelvic, soft tissue) often alongside other anaerobes.

field_notes.Indole: Indole reactions vary by species and method; interpret with caution.
field_notes.Glucose Fermentation: Carbohydrate utilization is often limited/variable across anaerobic cocci.
field_notes.Haemolysis: May be absent or variable depending on medium and incubation conditions.

key_differentiators.notes: Obligate anaerobic growth separates Peptostreptococcus from common aerobic/facultative Gram-positive cocci.
Catalase negativity supports anaerobic cocci over staphylococci/micrococci.
Helps keep separation from anaerobic rods when the Gram stain is clear.

common_confusions.reason: Overlapping anaerobic cocci phenotype; biochemical panels often insufficient for confident separation.
Similar colony morphology and low biochemical activity; species-level calls often require MALDI-TOF.
Clinical overlap and similar anaerobic cocci appearance in polymicrobial infections.

when_to_question_identification: Robust aerobic growth suggests an aerotolerant or facultative genus, not Peptostreptococcus.
Strong catalase positivity suggests staphylococci or related genera.
Marked carbohydrate fermentation across many sugars is atypical for this genus-level profile.

recommended_next_tests.test: Aerotolerance / anaerobic confirmation (growth in air vs anaerobic)
recommended_next_tests.reason: Confirms obligate anaerobe status before species-level workup.
Useful discriminator for some anaerobic cocci species (method-dependent).
Most reliable approach for genus/species-level identification among anaerobic cocci.
